system: You are a resident physician tasked with writing a discharge summary letter of a patient from the patient's Electronic Health Records.
user:
The letter is written to a patient when leaving hospital after a stay for the review. It should be prose and not contain bullet points.
Include summary of stay including, if applicable, key issues, interventions, procedures, and treatments.
Include summary of condition at discharge.
Include recommendations for follow-up plans and ongoing treatment.
Write the text in the style of a discharge letter using medical terminology. Proceed chronologically, write factually, objectively and concretely, formally, professionally, politely, respectfully. Avoid generalizations, assumptions, verbose and cumbersome formulations, and redundancy. Do not invent or presume anything. Generally, formulate in the imperfect tense, reported speech from individuals (e.g., from patients) in subjunctive I, and medical assessments and diagnoses in the present tense.
Minimize hallucinations. Do not generate recommendations on your own or add anything. Write nothing about topics for which there is no information basis from the EHR.
Don't include all private information, such as ID and date of birth. Use ___ to represent names of patients and medical professionals.

Dear ___,

Upon your discharge on March 12, 2024, from [Your Hospital’s Name], we provide you with a summary of your hospital stay and the ongoing care plan as discussed during your discharge process.

You were admitted to our facility on March 10, 2024, due to the onset of chest pain (CP) and shortness of breath (SoB) which were significant enough to require transportation by ambulance. An electrocardiogram (ECG) conducted upon your arrival at the emergency department revealed ST elevation in leads V5-V6, which indicated an ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). Your admission was necessitated by these findings as per local guidelines aimed at addressing acute coronary syndromes.

On March 11, 2024, during your hospital stay, further diagnostic tests were carried out. An additional ECG confirmed persistent ST elevation, and laboratory evaluations showed elevated levels of Troponin T, measured at 30 and 29 ng/L, which substantiates the diagnosis of myocardial infarction involving the left main coronary artery.

In response to these findings, you received medical management following standard protocols which included administration of Morphine (2-4 mg as needed) for pain management, Oxygen therapy (2-4 L/min) contingent on saturation levels, Nitroglycerin (0.4 mg every 5 minutes for a maximum of 3 doses if chest pain persisted), and a single dose of chewed Aspirin (324 mg) to reduce platelet aggregation. Local hospital guidelines recommended percutaneous coronary intervention (PCA); however, logistical issues arose due to the inability to arrange cath lab access promptly.

On March 12, 2024, you communicated the resolution of your chest pain and, based on this, requested discharge from hospital care. Your clinical status at the time of discharge indicated stabilization with resolution of acute symptoms.

For follow-up, it is crucial to engage in regular consultations with your cardiologist to monitor your cardiac health and to ensure adherence to any ongoing treatment plans. Please ensure that you comply with any prescribed medications or lifestyle modifications as guided by your medical professionals.

For any queries or additional information regarding your care, do not hesitate to contact us at [Your Hospital’s Contact Information].

We wish you a smooth recovery and good health.

Yours sincerely,

Dr. ___
